awd_titl_txt: RACE-GENDER TRAJECTORIES IN ENGINEERING: THE ROLE OF SOCIAL CONTROL ACROSS NEIGHBORHOOD AND SCHOOL CONTEXTS
awd_abstract_narration:
Meeting the nation's need for a larger, more diverse scientific and technological workforce requires new knowledge about how school and neighborhood contexts shape individuals' career trajectories. Research has yet to explore whether a heightened emphasis on social control in these environments provides a climate antithetical to the cultivation of adolescents' innovative thinking and creativity, attributes that are considered essential to their success in the engineering sciences. Research of this kind will be useful in identifying: 1) the school and neighborhood dimensions most strongly related to the dispositions and trajectories of underrepresented populations at key junctures of engineering pathways, and 2) the kind of educational reforms and neighborhood programs that will aid students' secondary school preparation, post-secondary persistence in the fields, and eventual entry into the engineering professions. In support of these important aims, this research applies advanced statistical methods to the ELS dataset to answer the following questions:   

1. What contextual structures, processes and effects in existing research are most related to race-gender groups' occupational attainment in engineering?

2. Are school and neighborhood social control strategies related to race-gender trajectories in secondary school preparation, post-secondary persistence, and entry into the engineering workforce? 

3. Is more variation in race-gender groups' engineering career trajectories accounted for by their neighborhood or school context? 

4. What causal inferences can be made about the engineering career trajectories of nearly identical race-gender groups that differ in their exposure to more or less restrictive methods of social control within neighborhoods and schools?

The transformative potential of this study extends from its capacity to fill multiple voids in our engineering workforce development and broadening participation knowledge base. Identifying neighborhood and school qualities associated with race-gender groups' likelihood of entering engineering science professions contributes specific knowledge about school and non-school contexts as sites of engineering career development. This project considers whether society's pursuit of social control and order establishes a climate within both contexts that is antithetical to the cultivation of adolescents' interest in engineering. Youth of color, African American and Latino males in particular, are most likely to be exposed to punitive social control strategies, and may become less likely to enter the engineering field as a consequence. To explore these possibilities, this project uses systematic literature review procedures and innovative quantitative methods to investigate the longitudinal career trajectories of participants in the Educational Longitudinal Study (ELS) of 2002. The research uses social control, intersectionality, and status attainment theories to frame the estimation of race-gender trajectories at critical stages of career development. This study aligns with NSF priorities and national calls to broaden the participation of historically underrepresented groups at all stages of their career development. Study results about the engineering experiences of race-gender groups within neighborhood and school contexts will reveal areas where investment and reforms can expand access and interest in engineering careers. The policy relevance of this research is significant and will inform decision-makers and practitioners about the human capital cost to engineering fields previously hidden in the uninvestigated effects of social control strategies. This study will offer potentially transformative recommendations for schools that, if adopted, would enable the replication of inclusive learning environments that align with expansive engineering opportunities.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded our investigation of the impact of students' exposure to social control within schools and neighborhoods on their secondary school preparation, post-secondary persistence, and entry into the engineering workforce. Social control in this study refers to the strategies schools use to maintain order and rule compliance, especially suspension from school, technologies of surveillance, invasive searches, and dress codes, among other methods that form the school to prison pipeline. Our work focused on social control because the same race-gender groups that are underrepresented in the STEM pipeline are overrepresented in the school-to-prison pipeline. We therefore tested the hypothesis that draining the school-to-prison pipeline would help fill the STEM pipeline, using mathematics performance and course taking as indicators of STEM. Additionally, we were interested in whether student experiences with social control would carry long-term consequences and impact their entry into college. Using nationally representative data from the Educational Longitudinal Study collected by the U.S. Dept. of Education, this project completed five analyses that address these hypotheses and have, as of November 2020, published four of them in scientific journals. We will highlight three of the main findings of these studies.

First, we learned that Black high school students were most likely to receive in-school suspensions and that these suspensions lowered their likelihood of taking advance math courses, even after the average levels of school social disorder were considered. We established that the effects of in-school suspension on mathematics outcomes were just as severe as the effects of out-of-school suspension, suggesting the recent decisions of schools to use in-school suspension instead of out-of-school suspension might make less progress in promoting mathematics course taking than hoped.  Second, Black students were four times more likely to attend a school that ranked in the upper third of schools in their use security cameras, metal detectors, drug sniffing dogs, and law enforcement during school hours than they were to attend a school that ranked in the lower third. 

Third, we learned that there is a social control setback in mathematics that all students experience, not just those that are suspended, within schools with greater surveillance, even after considering its rate of punishment (i.e. suspensions). We also find that attending a high social control school also lowers the likelihood students will attend college from 57 percent to 43 percent, after controlling for family background differences, average levels of social disorder, and prior academic performances. Based on these results, we argue that if schools reforms were able to reduce the influence of social control, disproportionate suspensions, and their impacts on math performances, young Black adolescents of both genders, would be more likely to enter college. Therefore our hypothesis that draining the school-to-prison pipeline would help fill the STEM pipeline was answered and upheld.

This project has also met its mentoring and research dissemination goals. Four doctoral students were among the authors of published work, and three of them have completed their dissertations in the course of their work with this project. On post-doctoral research fellow was also a first author of two published studies. Since these studies used machine learning techniques, multi-level statistical modeling, among other advanced research methods, project staff were well prepared to undertake cutting-edge research on STEM in the future. As project staff members, they have delivered at least 10 refereed presentations at scientific meetings, including the American Sociological Association, Society for the Study of Social Problems, the American Educational Research Association, and the American Society for Engineering Education, and at the annual meeting of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. In addition, the principal investigator has been invited to share research findings on at least 15 occasions at universities, and shared study results with school leaders, practitioners, and in several non-academic settings.
